title: USS Liberty: Copy of DoD Mandated Investigation of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: USS Liberty: Copy of DoD Mandated Investigation of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am a survivor of the June 8, 1967 Israeli attack on the USS Liberty and serve my shipmates as Historian of the USS Liberty Veterans Association. [https://ussliberty.com]

On June 8, 2005 the USS Liberty Veterans Association submitted “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967” to the Secretary of the Army in his capacity as Executive Agent for the Secretary of Defense. 

A copy of that report is at https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25497919-war-crimes-report-with-exhibits/.

The Department of Defense Law of War Manual requires “DoD policy has required that the commander of any unit that obtains information about a reportable incident shall immediately report the incident through the applicable operational command and Military Department.” [Paragraph 18.13.2, DoD Law of War Manual Page 1100]

The footnote on page 1100 states in part, “All reportable incidents committed by or against U.S. personnel, enemy persons, or any other individual are reported promptly, investigated thoroughly, and, where appropriate, remedied by corrective action.”

The DoD Law of War Manual is at https://dod.defense.gov/Portals/1/Documents/pubs/DoD%20Law%20of%20War%20Manual%20-%20June%202015%20Updated%20Dec%202016.pdf.

An excerpt of the relevant passage in the Law of War Manual is attached.

A reportable incident committed against U.S. personnel was reported to the Flag and other high-ranking US Navy officers serving on the US Navy Court of Inquiry when USS Liberty survivor Lloyd Painter testified under oath during the US Navy Court of Inquiry that he witnessed the IDF torpedo boats deliberately machine gunning of life rafts we had dropped over the side in anticipation of abandoning ship.

Upon receiving a copy of the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report, Painter noted that the portion of his testimony referenced above does not appear in the Report of the Court.

In his sworn deposition, Painter writes:

“1515 Hours: I climbed the ladder and opened the hatch to the main deck. I wanted to see if it was safe enough to bring the wounded sailors out onto the main deck. What I saw sent ice running through my veins. The life rafts were either destroyed or had been cut loose and had floated away. I personally observed an Israeli MTB methodically machine gun one of the Liberty's empty life rafts that had been cut loose and was floating in the water. I knew at that split second that the thrust of the IDF attack was to kill every American sailor on board. There were to be no survivors that day. I decided to leave all of the wounded sailors below decks for some measure of protection. I did not prepare to abandon ship.”

We have attached a complete copy of Lloyd Painter’s sworn deposition to this request.

We are requesting a copy of the investigation of the War Crimes investigation that is mandated by the Department of Defense Manual.

We are further requesting a copy of all records related to or mentioning our submission of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”

WE ARE NOT ASKING FOR ANOTHER COPY OF A US NAVY COURT OF INQUIRY REPORT BUT FOR THE REPORT OF THE MANDATED INVESTIGATION, CONDUCTED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE DOD LAW OF WAR MANUAL, ESTABLISHED TO INVESTIGATE AND RESOLVE THE ALLEGATIONS CONTAINED IN OUR WAR CRIMES REPORT WHICH WE SUBMITTED TO THE DOD ON JUNE 8, 2005.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joe Meadors

title: Cadet Military Duty and Other Schedule/Matrix

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Cadet Military Duty and Other Schedule/Matrix
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

TO AVOID UNNECESSARY DELAYS IN PROCESSING, I REQUEST NOW THAT ANY ESTIMATED COST TO FILL MY REQUEST BE PROVIDED.

YOU DO NOT NEED TO ASK ME IF I WANT YOU TO PREPARE A COST ESTIMATE IF THERE IS ONE

For the 2023 - 24 and current academic year to date copies of the Corps weekly training schedule/matrix/duty schedules and or other records showing all military and other duty for the Corps of Cadets. A copy of one such record is attached. Based on my knowledge and belief this record consists of an excel spreadsheet including, at a minimum tabs covering  Master Schedule, Information Annex, Activities Annex, Athletics Annex.

I note these documents are in electrnic format (Word, Excel, etc.) and should be provided in that format. Further, being stored in electronic format I anticipate they are readily accessible and so do not warrant a processing delay or search fees.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Anonymous.

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Any accounting records or statistics on seized real estate, vehicles, firearms, funds in bank accounts, and seizures made by the department, as well as seizures made by federal authorities where the department receives a share under the MOUs the department has in place with numerous agencies describing how assets are to be divided.

- Records and data that outlines what was purchased using money from the fund, including dates, descriptions, and total spent. 

- Any annual reports produced civil asset forfeiture program.

- Documents showing the balance of any funds currently in the department Civil Asset Forfeiture fund.

-A list of all items seized through civil asset forfeiture and retained for use by the department

- Sales of non-monetary assets, receipts of sale for vehicles, or the destruction of other non-monetary assets

-Please also include any information relating to contested seizures. This request does not include court documents for individual forfeiture cases.
 
The period for this request is for the last 10 years.

Preferably released in .CSV form when possible

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to Department of Homeland Security for Multimedia Agreements for 2018
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All DHS Multimedia Agreements signed by the Department of Homeland Security for the year 2018.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Request to NASA for all 2024 TV collaborations

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to NASA for all 2024 TV collaborations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all the television productions that NASA has participated in the production of, in any capacity whatsoever, for the year 2024. Any and all such lists, full or partial, would be appreciated and may include, but are not limited to, entertainment liaison (ELO) reports, production assistance agreements, or similar internal documents. I request that you search for these documents in any location where they might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices, public affairs offices, and communications HQ.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: US Navy support for 2025 movie "Warfare" (directed by Alex Garland)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: US Navy support for 2025 movie "Warfare" (directed by Alex Garland)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to collaboration between the U.S. Navy and the production of the 2025 feature film "Warfare," directed by Alex Garland and produced by A24 films. Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the Navy and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Warfare," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

communications.subject: Ref: F-2025-09133
communications.communication:
Dear Jeremy Barr: 

This acknowledges you information access request to the U.S. Department of State.  Your request number is F-2025-09133. You will find additional information such as the date your request was received and your request status in your electronic portal page under this case number. 

If you requested expedited processing, a fee waiver, or if unusual circumstances apply, you will receive additional correspondence from us. 
For further assistance or to discuss any aspect of your request, you may contact our FOIA Requester Service Center or our FOIA Public Liaison via email to FOIAStatus@state.gov or by telephone at (202) 261-8484. (mailto:FOIAStatus@state.gov)
Regards, 
Office of Information Access Liaison 
Information Access Programs 
U.S. Department of State

communications.subject: Status Update for Request #F-2025-09133 with U.S. Department of State
communications.communication:
Dear Jeremy Barr, 

The status of your FOIA request #F-2025-09133 has been updated to the following status 'Received'. To learn more, you may log into the DoS FOIA Portal via the Application URL at https://pal.foia.state.gov. 
If that status is "On Hold", please review the email you received and provide the requested information. If you did not receive an email, please contact the FOIA Requester Service Center via email at FOIAStatus@state.gov. (mailto:FOIAStatus@state.gov) 
If that status is "Closed" or "Documents Delivered", then the Department's response will be emailed or mailed (via US Postal Service). Please check your email account (including junk/spam mail) for the Department's response OR allow 7 to 10 business days to receive the Department's response by US Postal Service mail.
Regards, 
U.S. Department of State

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Club Communications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

TO AVOID UNNECESSARY DELAYS IN PROCESSING, I REQUEST NOW THAT ANY ESTIMATED COST TO FILL MY REQUEST BE PROVIDED.

YOU DO NOT NEED TO ASK ME IF I WANT YOU TO PREPARE A COST ESTIMATE IF THERE IS ONE.

title: USS Liberty: Copy of DoD Mandated Investigation of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: USS Liberty: Copy of DoD Mandated Investigation of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am a survivor of the June 8, 1967 Israeli attack on the USS Liberty and serve my shipmates as Historian of the USS Liberty Veterans Association. [https://ussliberty.com]

On June 8, 2005 the USS Liberty Veterans Association submitted “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967” to the Secretary of the Army in his capacity as Executive Agent for the Secretary of Defense. 

A copy of that report is at https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25497919-war-crimes-report-with-exhibits/.

The Department of Defense Law of War Manual requires “DoD policy has required that the commander of any unit that obtains information about a reportable incident shall immediately report the incident through the applicable operational command and Military Department.” [Paragraph 18.13.2, DoD Law of War Manual Page 1100]

The footnote on page 1100 states in part, “All reportable incidents committed by or against U.S. personnel, enemy persons, or any other individual are reported promptly, investigated thoroughly, and, where appropriate, remedied by corrective action.”

The DoD Law of War Manual is at https://dod.defense.gov/Portals/1/Documents/pubs/DoD%20Law%20of%20War%20Manual%20-%20June%202015%20Updated%20Dec%202016.pdf.

An excerpt of the relevant passage in the Law of War Manual is attached.

A reportable incident committed against U.S. personnel was reported to the Flag and other high-ranking US Navy officers serving on the US Navy Court of Inquiry when USS Liberty survivor Lloyd Painter testified under oath during the US Navy Court of Inquiry that he witnessed the IDF torpedo boats deliberately machine gunning of life rafts we had dropped over the side in anticipation of abandoning ship.

Upon receiving a copy of the US Navy Court of Inquiry Report, Painter noted that the portion of his testimony referenced above does not appear in the Report of the Court.

In his sworn deposition, Painter writes:

“1515 Hours: I climbed the ladder and opened the hatch to the main deck. I wanted to see if it was safe enough to bring the wounded sailors out onto the main deck. What I saw sent ice running through my veins. The life rafts were either destroyed or had been cut loose and had floated away. I personally observed an Israeli MTB methodically machine gun one of the Liberty's empty life rafts that had been cut loose and was floating in the water. I knew at that split second that the thrust of the IDF attack was to kill every American sailor on board. There were to be no survivors that day. I decided to leave all of the wounded sailors below decks for some measure of protection. I did not prepare to abandon ship.”

We have attached a complete copy of Lloyd Painter’s sworn deposition to this request.

We are requesting a copy of the investigation of the War Crimes investigation that is mandated by the Department of Defense Manual.

We are further requesting a copy of all records related to or mentioning our submission of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”

WE ARE NOT ASKING FOR ANOTHER COPY OF A US NAVY COURT OF INQUIRY REPORT BUT FOR THE REPORT OF THE MANDATED INVESTIGATION, CONDUCTED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE DOD LAW OF WAR MANUAL, ESTABLISHED TO INVESTIGATE AND RESOLVE THE ALLEGATIONS CONTAINED IN OUR WAR CRIMES REPORT WHICH WE SUBMITTED TO THE DOD ON JUNE 8, 2005.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joe Meadors

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request: USS Liberty: Copy of DoD Mandated Investigation of “A Report: War Crimes Committed Against U.S. Military Personnel, June 8, 1967”
communications.communication:
Dear Joe Meadows, 

The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) holds historical 
records from government agencies in the executive branch that are selected 
for permanent retention. Records are generally not transferred to NARA 
custody until at least 25 to 30 years after the close of the records and 
the transfer of certain records can be delayed by years or decades. We also 
do not have records created at the local or state level. As the records you 
are requesting are too recent , if the records exist they would still be in 
the custody of the creating agency and you will need to file a request with 
them directly at:


Department of Defense 

https://www.dodig.mil/FOIA/Submit-FOIA/

If you are not satisfied with our action on this request, you have the 
right to file an administrative appeal within ninety (90) calendar days 
from the date of this letter. Appeals must be in writing and may be 
delivered by regular U.S. mail or by email. By filing an appeal, you 
preserve your rights under the Freedom of Information Act and present the 
deciding agency with an opportunity to review your request and reconsider 
its decision. If you submit your appeal by regular mail, it should be 
addressed to the Deputy Archivist of the United States (ND), National 
Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road, Room 4200, College 
Park, Maryland 20740-6001. Both the letter and envelope should be clearly 
marked “FOIA Appeal.” If you submit your appeal by email, please send it to 
foia@nara.gov, addressed to the Deputy Archivist, with the words “FOIA 
Appeal” in the subject line. Please be certain to explain why you believe 
this response does not meet the requirements of the Freedom of Information 
Act. All communications concerning this request should reference your FOIA 
tracking number.

If you would like the opportunity to discuss our response and attempt to 
resolve your dispute without initiating the appeals process, you may 
contact our FOIA Public Liaison for assistance:

Accessioned Executive Branch Records – Washington, DC Area

FOIA Requester Service Center: 301-837-3190

FOIA Public Liaison: Rebecca Calcagno

8601 Adelphi Road, Room 5500

College Park, MD 20740-6001

dc.foia.liaison@nara.gov

301-837-3190

 

You  may also contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) 
, the federal FOIA ombudsman, for assistance. OGIS offers mediation 
services to help resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and federal 
agencies. The contact information for OGIS is:

Special Access and FOIA Program (RF)

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

EOIR Policy Memo PM25-02 references says that despite prohibiting "secret" adjudications policies in 2021, the EOIR in the last five years has been "issuing secret operational policies related to case adjudications." That memo states that "As a result, any operational policy related to case adjudications issued in secret between February 1, 2021, and January 21, 2025, is no longer in effect." That memo is found here: https://www.justice.gov/eoir/media/1386541/dl?inline

As I am sure you are aware, an understanding of what rules an adjudicator is following and is bound to follow is a cornerstone of due process. If the EOIR in the last four years has been operating based on an untold number of "secret" policies that have guided its case adjudications, that information is absolutely critical for the public to know. It may inform every decision the agency has issued in the last four years. So, pursuant to the FOIA, I am asking for two things. 

1. Please produce all of the "secret" adjudications policies that Acting Director Owen references in PM25-02. And
2. Expedite the processing of this FOIA request. Expedited treatment is critical, because until these secret policies are known, individuals will be unable to determine if they were unlawfully removed or ordered removed as a result of such secret, unfair, and according to Acting Director Own likely illegal policies are known. 

Please promptly confirm receipt of this request, confirm that you have agreed to expedite it, and produce the records immediately. 

Thank you. 

Matthew Hoppock

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Hoppock

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Licensed officers and total employees
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all organized datasets containing the most recent information about the number of licensed officers and total employees per agency for every Virginia law enforcement agency,  in a machine-readable database or spreadsheet format such as Excel, CSV, Access, SQL or JSON. 

The data should include all fields in the database or spreadsheets that contain non-exempt information. I also request all documentation that describes the layout of the database’s tables and fields, and that provides the definitions of any field names, codes, and abbreviations used in the database. This information may be gathered together in a single document like a data dictionary, entity layout, or user's guide. If that is the case, I request access to and copy of said document.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Dillon Bergin.

title: Crime Incident Requests for 2009, 2011, 2013, and 2015 (San Diego Police Department)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
•	Year(s) Requested: 2009; 2011; 2013; 2015
•	Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block
